15#ifndef OPENSSL_HEADER_BYTESTRING_H
16#define OPENSSL_HEADER_BYTESTRING_H
17
18#include <openssl/base.h>
19
20#include <openssl/span.h>
21
22#if defined(__cplusplus)
23extern "C" {
24#endif
25
26
27// Bytestrings are used for parsing and building TLS and ASN.1 messages.
28//
29// A "CBS" (CRYPTO ByteString) represents a string of bytes in memory and
30// provides utility functions for safely parsing length-prefixed structures
31// like TLS and ASN.1 from it.
32//
33// A "CBB" (CRYPTO ByteBuilder) is a memory buffer that grows as needed and
34// provides utility functions for building length-prefixed messages.
35
36
37// CRYPTO ByteString
38
39struct cbs_st {
40 const uint8_t *data;
41 size_t len;
42
43#if !defined(BORINGSSL_NO_CXX)
44 // Allow implicit conversions to and from bssl::Span<const uint8_t>.
45 cbs_st(bssl::Span<const uint8_t> span)
46 : data(span.data()), len(span.size()) {}
47 operator bssl::Span<const uint8_t>() const {
48 return bssl::MakeConstSpan(data, len);
49 }
50
51 // Defining any constructors requires we explicitly default the others.
52 cbs_st() = default;
53 cbs_st(const cbs_st &) = default;
54#endif
55};
56
57// CBS_init sets |cbs| to point to |data|. It does not take ownership of
58// |data|.
59OPENSSL_EXPORT void CBS_init(CBS *cbs, const uint8_t *data, size_t len);
60
61// CBS_skip advances |cbs| by |len| bytes. It returns one on success and zero
62// otherwise.
63OPENSSL_EXPORT int CBS_skip(CBS *cbs, size_t len);
64
65// CBS_data returns a pointer to the contents of |cbs|.
66OPENSSL_EXPORT const uint8_t *CBS_data(const CBS *cbs);
67
68// CBS_len returns the number of bytes remaining in |cbs|.
69OPENSSL_EXPORT size_t CBS_len(const CBS *cbs);
70
71// CBS_stow copies the current contents of |cbs| into |*out_ptr| and
72// |*out_len|. If |*out_ptr| is not NULL, the contents are freed with
73// OPENSSL_free. It returns one on success and zero on allocation failure. On
74// success, |*out_ptr| should be freed with OPENSSL_free. If |cbs| is empty,
75// |*out_ptr| will be NULL.
76OPENSSL_EXPORT int CBS_stow(const CBS *cbs, uint8_t **out_ptr, size_t *out_len);
77
78// CBS_strdup copies the current contents of |cbs| into |*out_ptr| as a
79// NUL-terminated C string. If |*out_ptr| is not NULL, the contents are freed
80// with OPENSSL_free. It returns one on success and zero on allocation
81// failure. On success, |*out_ptr| should be freed with OPENSSL_free.
82//
83// NOTE: If |cbs| contains NUL bytes, the string will be truncated. Call
84// |CBS_contains_zero_byte(cbs)| to check for NUL bytes.
85OPENSSL_EXPORT int CBS_strdup(const CBS *cbs, char **out_ptr);
86
87// CBS_contains_zero_byte returns one if the current contents of |cbs| contains
88// a NUL byte and zero otherwise.
89OPENSSL_EXPORT int CBS_contains_zero_byte(const CBS *cbs);
90
91// CBS_mem_equal compares the current contents of |cbs| with the |len| bytes
92// starting at |data|. If they're equal, it returns one, otherwise zero. If the
93// lengths match, it uses a constant-time comparison.
94OPENSSL_EXPORT int CBS_mem_equal(const CBS *cbs, const uint8_t *data,
95 size_t len);
96
97// CBS_get_u8 sets |*out| to the next uint8_t from |cbs| and advances |cbs|. It
98// returns one on success and zero on error.
99OPENSSL_EXPORT int CBS_get_u8(CBS *cbs, uint8_t *out);
100
101// CBS_get_u16 sets |*out| to the next, big-endian uint16_t from |cbs| and
102// advances |cbs|. It returns one on success and zero on error.
103OPENSSL_EXPORT int CBS_get_u16(CBS *cbs, uint16_t *out);
104
105// CBS_get_u16le sets |*out| to the next, little-endian uint16_t from |cbs| and
106// advances |cbs|. It returns one on success and zero on error.
107OPENSSL_EXPORT int CBS_get_u16le(CBS *cbs, uint16_t *out);
108
109// CBS_get_u24 sets |*out| to the next, big-endian 24-bit value from |cbs| and
110// advances |cbs|. It returns one on success and zero on error.
111OPENSSL_EXPORT int CBS_get_u24(CBS *cbs, uint32_t *out);
112
113// CBS_get_u32 sets |*out| to the next, big-endian uint32_t value from |cbs|
114// and advances |cbs|. It returns one on success and zero on error.
115OPENSSL_EXPORT int CBS_get_u32(CBS *cbs, uint32_t *out);
116
117// CBS_get_u32le sets |*out| to the next, little-endian uint32_t value from
118// |cbs| and advances |cbs|. It returns one on success and zero on error.
119OPENSSL_EXPORT int CBS_get_u32le(CBS *cbs, uint32_t *out);
120
121// CBS_get_u64 sets |*out| to the next, big-endian uint64_t value from |cbs|
122// and advances |cbs|. It returns one on success and zero on error.
123OPENSSL_EXPORT int CBS_get_u64(CBS *cbs, uint64_t *out);
124
125// CBS_get_u64le sets |*out| to the next, little-endian uint64_t value from
126// |cbs| and advances |cbs|. It returns one on success and zero on error.
127OPENSSL_EXPORT int CBS_get_u64le(CBS *cbs, uint64_t *out);
128
129// CBS_get_last_u8 sets |*out| to the last uint8_t from |cbs| and shortens
130// |cbs|. It returns one on success and zero on error.
131OPENSSL_EXPORT int CBS_get_last_u8(CBS *cbs, uint8_t *out);
132
133// CBS_get_bytes sets |*out| to the next |len| bytes from |cbs| and advances
134// |cbs|. It returns one on success and zero on error.
135OPENSSL_EXPORT int CBS_get_bytes(CBS *cbs, CBS *out, size_t len);
136
137// CBS_copy_bytes copies the next |len| bytes from |cbs| to |out| and advances
138// |cbs|. It returns one on success and zero on error.
139OPENSSL_EXPORT int CBS_copy_bytes(CBS *cbs, uint8_t *out, size_t len);
140
141// CBS_get_u8_length_prefixed sets |*out| to the contents of an 8-bit,
142// length-prefixed value from |cbs| and advances |cbs| over it. It returns one
143// on success and zero on error.
144OPENSSL_EXPORT int CBS_get_u8_length_prefixed(CBS *cbs, CBS *out);
145
146// CBS_get_u16_length_prefixed sets |*out| to the contents of a 16-bit,
147// big-endian, length-prefixed value from |cbs| and advances |cbs| over it. It
148// returns one on success and zero on error.
149OPENSSL_EXPORT int CBS_get_u16_length_prefixed(CBS *cbs, CBS *out);
150
151// CBS_get_u24_length_prefixed sets |*out| to the contents of a 24-bit,
152// big-endian, length-prefixed value from |cbs| and advances |cbs| over it. It
153// returns one on success and zero on error.
154OPENSSL_EXPORT int CBS_get_u24_length_prefixed(CBS *cbs, CBS *out);
155
156
157// Parsing ASN.1
158//
159// |CBS| may be used to parse DER structures. Rather than using a schema
160// compiler, the following functions act on tag-length-value elements in the
161// serialization itself. Thus the caller is responsible for looping over a
162// SEQUENCE, branching on CHOICEs or OPTIONAL fields, checking for trailing
163// data, and handling explict vs. implicit tagging.
164//
165// Tags are represented as |unsigned| values in memory. The upper few bits store
166// the class and constructed bit, and the remaining bits store the tag
167// number. Note this differs from the DER serialization, to support tag numbers
168// beyond 31. Consumers must use the constants defined below to decompose or
169// assemble tags.
170//
171// This library treats an element's constructed bit as part of its tag. In DER,
172// the constructed bit is computable from the type. The constants for universal
173// types have the bit set. Callers must set it correctly for tagged types.
174// Explicitly-tagged types are always constructed, and implicitly-tagged types
175// inherit the underlying type's bit.
176
177// CBS_ASN1_TAG_SHIFT is how much the in-memory representation shifts the class
178// and constructed bits from the DER serialization.
179#define CBS_ASN1_TAG_SHIFT 24
180
181// CBS_ASN1_CONSTRUCTED may be ORed into a tag to set the constructed bit.
182#define CBS_ASN1_CONSTRUCTED (0x20u << CBS_ASN1_TAG_SHIFT)
183
184// The following values specify the tag class and may be ORed into a tag number
185// to produce the final tag. If none is used, the tag will be UNIVERSAL.
186#define CBS_ASN1_UNIVERSAL (0u << CBS_ASN1_TAG_SHIFT)
187#define CBS_ASN1_APPLICATION (0x40u << CBS_ASN1_TAG_SHIFT)
188#define CBS_ASN1_CONTEXT_SPECIFIC (0x80u << CBS_ASN1_TAG_SHIFT)
189#define CBS_ASN1_PRIVATE (0xc0u << CBS_ASN1_TAG_SHIFT)
190
191// CBS_ASN1_CLASS_MASK may be ANDed with a tag to query its class. This will
192// give one of the four values above.
193#define CBS_ASN1_CLASS_MASK (0xc0u << CBS_ASN1_TAG_SHIFT)
194
195// CBS_ASN1_TAG_NUMBER_MASK may be ANDed with a tag to query its number.
196#define CBS_ASN1_TAG_NUMBER_MASK ((1u << (5 + CBS_ASN1_TAG_SHIFT)) - 1)
197
198// The following values are constants for UNIVERSAL tags. Note these constants
199// include the constructed bit.
200#define CBS_ASN1_BOOLEAN 0x1u
201#define CBS_ASN1_INTEGER 0x2u
202#define CBS_ASN1_BITSTRING 0x3u
203#define CBS_ASN1_OCTETSTRING 0x4u
204#define CBS_ASN1_NULL 0x5u
205#define CBS_ASN1_OBJECT 0x6u
206#define CBS_ASN1_ENUMERATED 0xau
207#define CBS_ASN1_UTF8STRING 0xcu
208#define CBS_ASN1_SEQUENCE (0x10u | CBS_ASN1_CONSTRUCTED)
209#define CBS_ASN1_SET (0x11u | CBS_ASN1_CONSTRUCTED)
210#define CBS_ASN1_NUMERICSTRING 0x12u
211#define CBS_ASN1_PRINTABLESTRING 0x13u
212#define CBS_ASN1_T61STRING 0x14u
213#define CBS_ASN1_VIDEOTEXSTRING 0x15u
214#define CBS_ASN1_IA5STRING 0x16u
215#define CBS_ASN1_UTCTIME 0x17u
216#define CBS_ASN1_GENERALIZEDTIME 0x18u
217#define CBS_ASN1_GRAPHICSTRING 0x19u
218#define CBS_ASN1_VISIBLESTRING 0x1au
219#define CBS_ASN1_GENERALSTRING 0x1bu
220#define CBS_ASN1_UNIVERSALSTRING 0x1cu
221#define CBS_ASN1_BMPSTRING 0x1eu
222
223// CBS_get_asn1 sets |*out| to the contents of DER-encoded, ASN.1 element (not
224// including tag and length bytes) and advances |cbs| over it. The ASN.1
225// element must match |tag_value|. It returns one on success and zero
226// on error.
227OPENSSL_EXPORT int CBS_get_asn1(CBS *cbs, CBS *out, unsigned tag_value);
228
229// CBS_get_asn1_element acts like |CBS_get_asn1| but |out| will include the
230// ASN.1 header bytes too.
231OPENSSL_EXPORT int CBS_get_asn1_element(CBS *cbs, CBS *out, unsigned tag_value);
232
233// CBS_peek_asn1_tag looks ahead at the next ASN.1 tag and returns one
234// if the next ASN.1 element on |cbs| would have tag |tag_value|. If
235// |cbs| is empty or the tag does not match, it returns zero. Note: if
236// it returns one, CBS_get_asn1 may still fail if the rest of the
237// element is malformed.
238OPENSSL_EXPORT int CBS_peek_asn1_tag(const CBS *cbs, unsigned tag_value);
239
240// CBS_get_any_asn1 sets |*out| to contain the next ASN.1 element from |*cbs|
241// (not including tag and length bytes), sets |*out_tag| to the tag number, and
242// advances |*cbs|. It returns one on success and zero on error. Either of |out|
243// and |out_tag| may be NULL to ignore the value.
244OPENSSL_EXPORT int CBS_get_any_asn1(CBS *cbs, CBS *out, unsigned *out_tag);
245
246// CBS_get_any_asn1_element sets |*out| to contain the next ASN.1 element from
247// |*cbs| (including header bytes) and advances |*cbs|. It sets |*out_tag| to
248// the tag number and |*out_header_len| to the length of the ASN.1 header. Each
249// of |out|, |out_tag|, and |out_header_len| may be NULL to ignore the value.
250OPENSSL_EXPORT int CBS_get_any_asn1_element(CBS *cbs, CBS *out,
251 unsigned *out_tag,
252 size_t *out_header_len);
253
254// CBS_get_any_ber_asn1_element acts the same as |CBS_get_any_asn1_element| but
255// also allows indefinite-length elements to be returned and does not enforce
256// that lengths are minimal. For indefinite-lengths, |*out_header_len| and
257// |CBS_len(out)| will be equal as only the header is returned (although this is
258// also true for empty elements so the length must be checked too). If
259// |out_ber_found| is not NULL then it is set to one if any case of invalid DER
260// but valid BER is found, and to zero otherwise.
261OPENSSL_EXPORT int CBS_get_any_ber_asn1_element(CBS *cbs, CBS *out,
262 unsigned *out_tag,
263 size_t *out_header_len,
264 int *out_ber_found);
265
266// CBS_get_asn1_uint64 gets an ASN.1 INTEGER from |cbs| using |CBS_get_asn1|
267// and sets |*out| to its value. It returns one on success and zero on error,
268// where error includes the integer being negative, or too large to represent
269// in 64 bits.
270OPENSSL_EXPORT int CBS_get_asn1_uint64(CBS *cbs, uint64_t *out);
271
272// CBS_get_asn1_int64 gets an ASN.1 INTEGER from |cbs| using |CBS_get_asn1|
273// and sets |*out| to its value. It returns one on success and zero on error,
274// where error includes the integer being too large to represent in 64 bits.
275OPENSSL_EXPORT int CBS_get_asn1_int64(CBS *cbs, int64_t *out);
276
277// CBS_get_asn1_bool gets an ASN.1 BOOLEAN from |cbs| and sets |*out| to zero
278// or one based on its value. It returns one on success or zero on error.
279OPENSSL_EXPORT int CBS_get_asn1_bool(CBS *cbs, int *out);
280
281// CBS_get_optional_asn1 gets an optional explicitly-tagged element from |cbs|
282// tagged with |tag| and sets |*out| to its contents, or ignores it if |out| is
283// NULL. If present and if |out_present| is not NULL, it sets |*out_present| to
284// one, otherwise zero. It returns one on success, whether or not the element
285// was present, and zero on decode failure.
286OPENSSL_EXPORT int CBS_get_optional_asn1(CBS *cbs, CBS *out, int *out_present,
287 unsigned tag);
288
289// CBS_get_optional_asn1_octet_string gets an optional
290// explicitly-tagged OCTET STRING from |cbs|. If present, it sets
291// |*out| to the string and |*out_present| to one. Otherwise, it sets
292// |*out| to empty and |*out_present| to zero. |out_present| may be
293// NULL. It returns one on success, whether or not the element was
294// present, and zero on decode failure.
295OPENSSL_EXPORT int CBS_get_optional_asn1_octet_string(CBS *cbs, CBS *out,
296 int *out_present,
297 unsigned tag);
298
299// CBS_get_optional_asn1_uint64 gets an optional explicitly-tagged
300// INTEGER from |cbs|. If present, it sets |*out| to the
301// value. Otherwise, it sets |*out| to |default_value|. It returns one
302// on success, whether or not the element was present, and zero on
303// decode failure.
304OPENSSL_EXPORT int CBS_get_optional_asn1_uint64(CBS *cbs, uint64_t *out,
305 unsigned tag,
306 uint64_t default_value);
307
308// CBS_get_optional_asn1_bool gets an optional, explicitly-tagged BOOLEAN from
309// |cbs|. If present, it sets |*out| to either zero or one, based on the
310// boolean. Otherwise, it sets |*out| to |default_value|. It returns one on
311// success, whether or not the element was present, and zero on decode
312// failure.
313OPENSSL_EXPORT int CBS_get_optional_asn1_bool(CBS *cbs, int *out, unsigned tag,
314 int default_value);
315
316// CBS_is_valid_asn1_bitstring returns one if |cbs| is a valid ASN.1 BIT STRING
317// body and zero otherwise.
318OPENSSL_EXPORT int CBS_is_valid_asn1_bitstring(const CBS *cbs);
319
320// CBS_asn1_bitstring_has_bit returns one if |cbs| is a valid ASN.1 BIT STRING
321// body and the specified bit is present and set. Otherwise, it returns zero.
322// |bit| is indexed starting from zero.
323OPENSSL_EXPORT int CBS_asn1_bitstring_has_bit(const CBS *cbs, unsigned bit);
324
325// CBS_is_valid_asn1_integer returns one if |cbs| is a valid ASN.1 INTEGER,
326// body and zero otherwise. On success, if |out_is_negative| is non-NULL,
327// |*out_is_negative| will be set to one if |cbs| is negative and zero
328// otherwise.
329OPENSSL_EXPORT int CBS_is_valid_asn1_integer(const CBS *cbs,
330 int *out_is_negative);
331
332// CBS_is_unsigned_asn1_integer returns one if |cbs| is a valid non-negative
333// ASN.1 INTEGER body and zero otherwise.
334OPENSSL_EXPORT int CBS_is_unsigned_asn1_integer(const CBS *cbs);
335
336// CBS_asn1_oid_to_text interprets |cbs| as DER-encoded ASN.1 OBJECT IDENTIFIER
337// contents (not including the element framing) and returns the ASCII
338// representation (e.g., "1.2.840.113554.4.1.72585") in a newly-allocated
339// string, or NULL on failure. The caller must release the result with
340// |OPENSSL_free|.
341OPENSSL_EXPORT char *CBS_asn1_oid_to_text(const CBS *cbs);
342
343
344// CRYPTO ByteBuilder.
345//
346// |CBB| objects allow one to build length-prefixed serialisations. A |CBB|
347// object is associated with a buffer and new buffers are created with
348// |CBB_init|. Several |CBB| objects can point at the same buffer when a
349// length-prefix is pending, however only a single |CBB| can be 'current' at
350// any one time. For example, if one calls |CBB_add_u8_length_prefixed| then
351// the new |CBB| points at the same buffer as the original. But if the original
352// |CBB| is used then the length prefix is written out and the new |CBB| must
353// not be used again.
354//
355// If one needs to force a length prefix to be written out because a |CBB| is
356// going out of scope, use |CBB_flush|. If an operation on a |CBB| fails, it is
357// in an undefined state and must not be used except to call |CBB_cleanup|.
358
359struct cbb_buffer_st {
360 uint8_t *buf;
361 size_t len; // The number of valid bytes.
362 size_t cap; // The size of buf.
363 char can_resize; /* One iff |buf| is owned by this object. If not then |buf|
364 cannot be resized. */
365 char error; /* One iff there was an error writing to this CBB. All future
366 operations will fail. */
367};
368
369struct cbb_st {
370 struct cbb_buffer_st *base;
371 // child points to a child CBB if a length-prefix is pending.
372 CBB *child;
373 // offset is the number of bytes from the start of |base->buf| to this |CBB|'s
374 // pending length prefix.
375 size_t offset;
376 // pending_len_len contains the number of bytes in this |CBB|'s pending
377 // length-prefix, or zero if no length-prefix is pending.
378 uint8_t pending_len_len;
379 char pending_is_asn1;
380 // is_child is true iff this is a child |CBB| (as opposed to a top-level
381 // |CBB|). Top-level objects are valid arguments for |CBB_finish|.
382 char is_child;
383};
384
385// CBB_zero sets an uninitialised |cbb| to the zero state. It must be
386// initialised with |CBB_init| or |CBB_init_fixed| before use, but it is safe to
387// call |CBB_cleanup| without a successful |CBB_init|. This may be used for more
388// uniform cleanup of a |CBB|.
389OPENSSL_EXPORT void CBB_zero(CBB *cbb);
390
391// CBB_init initialises |cbb| with |initial_capacity|. Since a |CBB| grows as
392// needed, the |initial_capacity| is just a hint. It returns one on success or
393// zero on allocation failure.
394OPENSSL_EXPORT int CBB_init(CBB *cbb, size_t initial_capacity);
395
396// CBB_init_fixed initialises |cbb| to write to |len| bytes at |buf|. Since
397// |buf| cannot grow, trying to write more than |len| bytes will cause CBB
398// functions to fail. It returns one on success or zero on error.
399OPENSSL_EXPORT int CBB_init_fixed(CBB *cbb, uint8_t *buf, size_t len);
400
401// CBB_cleanup frees all resources owned by |cbb| and other |CBB| objects
402// writing to the same buffer. This should be used in an error case where a
403// serialisation is abandoned.
404//
405// This function can only be called on a "top level" |CBB|, i.e. one initialised
406// with |CBB_init| or |CBB_init_fixed|, or a |CBB| set to the zero state with
407// |CBB_zero|.
408OPENSSL_EXPORT void CBB_cleanup(CBB *cbb);
409
410// CBB_finish completes any pending length prefix and sets |*out_data| to a
411// malloced buffer and |*out_len| to the length of that buffer. The caller
412// takes ownership of the buffer and, unless the buffer was fixed with
413// |CBB_init_fixed|, must call |OPENSSL_free| when done.
414//
415// It can only be called on a "top level" |CBB|, i.e. one initialised with
416// |CBB_init| or |CBB_init_fixed|. It returns one on success and zero on
417// error.
418OPENSSL_EXPORT int CBB_finish(CBB *cbb, uint8_t **out_data, size_t *out_len);
419
420// CBB_flush causes any pending length prefixes to be written out and any child
421// |CBB| objects of |cbb| to be invalidated. This allows |cbb| to continue to be
422// used after the children go out of scope, e.g. when local |CBB| objects are
423// added as children to a |CBB| that persists after a function returns. This
424// function returns one on success or zero on error.
425OPENSSL_EXPORT int CBB_flush(CBB *cbb);
426
427// CBB_data returns a pointer to the bytes written to |cbb|. It does not flush
428// |cbb|. The pointer is valid until the next operation to |cbb|.
429//
430// To avoid unfinalized length prefixes, it is a fatal error to call this on a
431// CBB with any active children.
432OPENSSL_EXPORT const uint8_t *CBB_data(const CBB *cbb);
433
434// CBB_len returns the number of bytes written to |cbb|. It does not flush
435// |cbb|.
436//
437// To avoid unfinalized length prefixes, it is a fatal error to call this on a
438// CBB with any active children.
439OPENSSL_EXPORT size_t CBB_len(const CBB *cbb);
440
441// CBB_add_u8_length_prefixed sets |*out_contents| to a new child of |cbb|. The
442// data written to |*out_contents| will be prefixed in |cbb| with an 8-bit
443// length. It returns one on success or zero on error.
444OPENSSL_EXPORT int CBB_add_u8_length_prefixed(CBB *cbb, CBB *out_contents);
445
446// CBB_add_u16_length_prefixed sets |*out_contents| to a new child of |cbb|.
447// The data written to |*out_contents| will be prefixed in |cbb| with a 16-bit,
448// big-endian length. It returns one on success or zero on error.
449OPENSSL_EXPORT int CBB_add_u16_length_prefixed(CBB *cbb, CBB *out_contents);
450
451// CBB_add_u24_length_prefixed sets |*out_contents| to a new child of |cbb|.
452// The data written to |*out_contents| will be prefixed in |cbb| with a 24-bit,
453// big-endian length. It returns one on success or zero on error.
454OPENSSL_EXPORT int CBB_add_u24_length_prefixed(CBB *cbb, CBB *out_contents);
455
456// CBB_add_asn1 sets |*out_contents| to a |CBB| into which the contents of an
457// ASN.1 object can be written. The |tag| argument will be used as the tag for
458// the object. It returns one on success or zero on error.
459OPENSSL_EXPORT int CBB_add_asn1(CBB *cbb, CBB *out_contents, unsigned tag);
460
461// CBB_add_bytes appends |len| bytes from |data| to |cbb|. It returns one on
462// success and zero otherwise.
463OPENSSL_EXPORT int CBB_add_bytes(CBB *cbb, const uint8_t *data, size_t len);
464
465// CBB_add_space appends |len| bytes to |cbb| and sets |*out_data| to point to
466// the beginning of that space. The caller must then write |len| bytes of
467// actual contents to |*out_data|. It returns one on success and zero
468// otherwise.
469OPENSSL_EXPORT int CBB_add_space(CBB *cbb, uint8_t **out_data, size_t len);
470
471// CBB_reserve ensures |cbb| has room for |len| additional bytes and sets
472// |*out_data| to point to the beginning of that space. It returns one on
473// success and zero otherwise. The caller may write up to |len| bytes to
474// |*out_data| and call |CBB_did_write| to complete the write. |*out_data| is
475// valid until the next operation on |cbb| or an ancestor |CBB|.
476OPENSSL_EXPORT int CBB_reserve(CBB *cbb, uint8_t **out_data, size_t len);
477
478// CBB_did_write advances |cbb| by |len| bytes, assuming the space has been
479// written to by the caller. It returns one on success and zero on error.
480OPENSSL_EXPORT int CBB_did_write(CBB *cbb, size_t len);
481
482// CBB_add_u8 appends an 8-bit number from |value| to |cbb|. It returns one on
483// success and zero otherwise.
484OPENSSL_EXPORT int CBB_add_u8(CBB *cbb, uint8_t value);
485
486// CBB_add_u16 appends a 16-bit, big-endian number from |value| to |cbb|. It
487// returns one on success and zero otherwise.
488OPENSSL_EXPORT int CBB_add_u16(CBB *cbb, uint16_t value);
489
490// CBB_add_u16le appends a 16-bit, little-endian number from |value| to |cbb|.
491// It returns one on success and zero otherwise.
492OPENSSL_EXPORT int CBB_add_u16le(CBB *cbb, uint16_t value);
493
494// CBB_add_u24 appends a 24-bit, big-endian number from |value| to |cbb|. It
495// returns one on success and zero otherwise.
496OPENSSL_EXPORT int CBB_add_u24(CBB *cbb, uint32_t value);
497
498// CBB_add_u32 appends a 32-bit, big-endian number from |value| to |cbb|. It
499// returns one on success and zero otherwise.
500OPENSSL_EXPORT int CBB_add_u32(CBB *cbb, uint32_t value);
501
502// CBB_add_u32le appends a 32-bit, little-endian number from |value| to |cbb|.
503// It returns one on success and zero otherwise.
504OPENSSL_EXPORT int CBB_add_u32le(CBB *cbb, uint32_t value);
505
506// CBB_add_u64 appends a 64-bit, big-endian number from |value| to |cbb|. It
507// returns one on success and zero otherwise.
508OPENSSL_EXPORT int CBB_add_u64(CBB *cbb, uint64_t value);
509
510// CBB_add_u64le appends a 64-bit, little-endian number from |value| to |cbb|.
511// It returns one on success and zero otherwise.
512OPENSSL_EXPORT int CBB_add_u64le(CBB *cbb, uint64_t value);
513
514// CBB_discard_child discards the current unflushed child of |cbb|. Neither the
515// child's contents nor the length prefix will be included in the output.
516OPENSSL_EXPORT void CBB_discard_child(CBB *cbb);
517
518// CBB_add_asn1_uint64 writes an ASN.1 INTEGER into |cbb| using |CBB_add_asn1|
519// and writes |value| in its contents. It returns one on success and zero on
520// error.
521OPENSSL_EXPORT int CBB_add_asn1_uint64(CBB *cbb, uint64_t value);
522
523// CBB_add_asn1_int64 writes an ASN.1 INTEGER into |cbb| using |CBB_add_asn1|
524// and writes |value| in its contents. It returns one on success and zero on
525// error.
526OPENSSL_EXPORT int CBB_add_asn1_int64(CBB *cbb, int64_t value);
527
528// CBB_add_asn1_octet_string writes an ASN.1 OCTET STRING into |cbb| with the
529// given contents. It returns one on success and zero on error.
530OPENSSL_EXPORT int CBB_add_asn1_octet_string(CBB *cbb, const uint8_t *data,
531 size_t data_len);
532
533// CBB_add_asn1_bool writes an ASN.1 BOOLEAN into |cbb| which is true iff
534// |value| is non-zero. It returns one on success and zero on error.
535OPENSSL_EXPORT int CBB_add_asn1_bool(CBB *cbb, int value);
536
537// CBB_add_asn1_oid_from_text decodes |len| bytes from |text| as an ASCII OID
538// representation, e.g. "1.2.840.113554.4.1.72585", and writes the DER-encoded
539// contents to |cbb|. It returns one on success and zero on malloc failure or if
540// |text| was invalid. It does not include the OBJECT IDENTIFER framing, only
541// the element's contents.
542//
543// This function considers OID strings with components which do not fit in a
544// |uint64_t| to be invalid.
545OPENSSL_EXPORT int CBB_add_asn1_oid_from_text(CBB *cbb, const char *text,
546 size_t len);
547
548// CBB_flush_asn1_set_of calls |CBB_flush| on |cbb| and then reorders the
549// contents for a DER-encoded ASN.1 SET OF type. It returns one on success and
550// zero on failure. DER canonicalizes SET OF contents by sorting
551// lexicographically by encoding. Call this function when encoding a SET OF
552// type in an order that is not already known to be canonical.
553//
554// Note a SET type has a slightly different ordering than a SET OF.
555OPENSSL_EXPORT int CBB_flush_asn1_set_of(CBB *cbb);
556
557
558#if defined(__cplusplus)
559} // extern C
560
561
562#if !defined(BORINGSSL_NO_CXX)
563extern "C++" {
564
565BSSL_NAMESPACE_BEGIN
566
567using ScopedCBB = internal::StackAllocated<CBB, void, CBB_zero, CBB_cleanup>;
568
569BSSL_NAMESPACE_END
570
571} // extern C++
572#endif
573
574#endif
575
576#endif // OPENSSL_HEADER_BYTESTRING_H
